text: was a after Hōei and before Kyōhō. This period started in April 1711 and ended in June 1716.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Shōtoku" Japan Encyclopedia, p. 888. During this time, the emperor was .Nussbaum, "Nakamikado Tennō," p. 690; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 416-417. The nengō Shōtoku means "Correct Virtue".Screech, Timon. (2000). The Shogun's Painted Culture, p. 100. ==Events of the Shōtoku Era== * 1711 (Shōtoku 1): An ambassador from Korea was received at Court.Titsingh, p. 416. * 12 November 1712 (Shōtoku 2, 14th day of the 10th month): Shogun Tokugawa Ienobu died. * 1713 (Shōtoku 3): Tokugawa Ietsugu became the 7th shogun of the Tokugawa shogunate. * 1714 (Shōtoku 4): The shogunate introduced new gold and silver coins into circulation.Nussbaum, "Shōtoku-kingin" at p. 888. * 1714 (Shōtoku 4): The poet Nozawa Bonchō died.Nussbaum, "Bonchō" at p. 80. * 20 April 1715 (Shōtoku 5, 17th day of the 3rd month): The 100th anniversary of the death of Tokugawa Ieyasu was celebrated.Titsingh, pp. 416-417. ==Related pages == * Edo period == References == == Other websites == * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Shōtoku 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 1711 1712 1713 1714 1715 1716 Preceded by: Hōei Era or nengō: Shōtoku Succeeded by: Kyōhō Category:Japanese eras Category:1711 establishments Category:18th- century establishments in Japan Category:1710s disestablishments Category:18th-century disestablishments in Japan Category:1710s establishments in Asia
title: Shōtoku (era)
